title: District Cooling Systems: Technologies, Components, and Sustainable Engineering | Singapore Institute of Technology

meta.description: Learn the fundamentals of district cooling systems, including technologies, engineering principles, and sustainability strategies, to optimise efficiency and minimise environmental impact.

District Cooling Systems: Technologies, Components, and Sustainable Engineering
District Cooling Systems: Technologies, Components, and Sustainable Engineering
Learn the fundamentals of district cooling systems, including technologies, engineering principles, and sustainability strategies, to optimise efficiency and minimise environmental impact.

As demand for energy-efficient cooling rises, district cooling systems are vital for sustainability. Understanding the technologies and engineering optimises efficiency, cuts costs, and reduces environmental impact.

This course delves into the multifaceted world of district cooling, covering key technologies, engineering principles and practices, economic considerations, and future trends. Designed to equip learners with essential expertise, this masterclass provides in-depth knowledge and practical skills to navigate the dynamic district cooling landscape. Additionally, networking sessions offer valuable opportunities to connect with industry professionals and expand your expertise.
Bachelor’s Degree in Engineering or an Engineering Diploma with at least 2 years of relevant work experience.
Comprehensive Understanding of District Cooling Systems (DCS)
Gain an in-depth understanding of district cooling systems, including the technologies, engineering principles, and economic impact
Learn to plan, design, operate, and maintain efficient district cooling systems through hands-on workshops and case studies
Explore the economic aspects of district cooling, including cost-benefit analysis, financing models, and economic indicators
Understand the environmental impact of district cooling systems and learn how to align projects with regulatory standards and sustainability goals
Discover the role of district cooling in smart city planning, focusing on integration with emerging technologies and urban development strategies
Assistant Professor, Singapore Institute of Technology
Assistant Professor, Singapore Institute of Technology

Dr Swapnil Dubey is currently working as an Assistant Professor at the Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT), Singapore. Before joining SIT, he was working as a Principal Research Fellow and Team Leader at the Energy Research Institute at NTU (ERI@N), Nanyang Technological University, Singapore.

Dr Dubey is a mechanical engineer and received his PhD and Master’s degree from the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Delhi, India. He has 14+ years of experience in smart and sustainable technologies, building cooling and air distribution, building automation and control, net-zero and positive energy buildings, energy simulation and modelling, solar photovoltaic and thermal energy storage.

Dr Dubey has devoted significant research effort to address issues arising from rapid urbanisation and high-density urban living, which include cooling technologies, indoor environmental quality, urban sustainability, and microclimate. He has been involved in developing new intelligent building automation and control systems based on Model-Predictive Control (MPC) principles that brings predictive intelligence to modern buildings, allowing high level of energy efficiency and occupant well-being. The research received international recognition and led to innovations and commercial deployment in high profile green building projects in Singapore.

Dr Dubey has published over 80 peer-reviewed research papers, filed 6 patents, and published 2 books. He is a Singapore Certified Energy Manager (SCEM), a Green Mark Accredited Professional (GMAP), and a Full Member of ASHRAE, with a strong background in developing partnerships, digitalisation and decarbonisation strategies, consultancy projects, technology innovation, commercialisation and industry partnerships.

At SIT, Dr Dubey has also been involved in teaching undergraduate and post-graduate students on topics Air-conditioning and Mechanical Ventilation, Automation and Control in Buildings, District cooling system, Fluid Mechanics, Data Centre Cooling, as well as short-terms certification courses for working adults to upskill their knowledge.
Head of BD Mixed-Use Real Estate, ENGIE South East Asia
Head of BD Mixed-Use Real Estate, ENGIE South East Asia

Sebastien WALKER is currently Head of Business Development for Mixed use and Real Estate at ENGIE South East Asia, a part of ENGIE Group, one of the largest independent power producers in the world and a leader in energy efficiency services and sustainable infrastructure worldwide.

ENGIE partners with large corporations, businesses and local governments to assist them in meeting their energy needs with affordable, reliable and sustainable solutions as-a-service. Sebastien oversees business development activities across Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines and Australia to support and accelerate the journey towards carbon neutrality in the real estate sector.

Prior to this appointment, Sebastien was in charge of managing a portfolio of operating energy production assets. He also worked on the development of new and existing district energy schemes in France. Sebastien is an experienced strategy consultant for the energy sector, skilled in helping companies navigate the sector’s permutations and bringing new ideas to the market.
He holds a master’s degree in political science and business administration, as well as a Post-Master’s Degree in Energy Management from Mines Paristech and Tsinghua University.
Chief Technical Officer, ENGIE South East Asia
Chief Technical Officer, ENGIE South East Asia

Anne Miclo is the CTO of ENGIE South East Asia, focusing on energy efficiency for commercial and industrial buildings. She has extensive experience in the technical, legal, and financial aspects of the energy sector across multiple countries. Anne is dedicated to advancing sustainable energy solutions in smart cities.
Project Director, ENGIE South East Asia
Project Director, ENGIE South East Asia

Dr Lu LU currently is the project director of District Cooling System (DCS) projects for both JTC and SIT developments in Punggol Digital District (PDD). He was involved in technical and commercial development in the initial project period. He is leading project management for both DCS projects in the construction phase.

Dr Lu is a BCA registered energy auditor and Singapore Certified Energy Manager (SCEM). He was involved in various energy efficiency projects, covering audit, implementation and M&V, the whole cycle of the energy performance process.

Dr Lu holds a bachelor’s and Master’s Degree in Electrical and Electronic Engineering from Xi’an Jiaotong University anda PhD in Electrical and Electronic Engineering from Nanyang Technologies University.
Programme Manager, ENGIE South East Asia
Programme Manager, ENGIE South East Asia

Lei Yu is currently a Senior Program Manager at Engie Singapore Lab, recognised for his innovative contributions to engineering and sustainability. With 20 years of experience in fluid dynamics, heat transfer, HVAC system design and applications, Lei has held key project and people management roles in Fortune 500 companies like Samsung Electronics, United Technologies and Carrier in China and the United States.

Lei holds a Master of Science and Bachelor of Engineering in Thermal Engineering from Tsinghua University(China) in 2003, an MBA from École des Ponts ParisTech - Tongji University in 2010, and a PMP certification from Singapore in 2021. He excels in innovation, strategic leadership, and a competitive drive to succeed.
Morning session: Overview and Fundamentals of District Cooling System (DCS)
Importance of district cooling in sustainable development
Basics, definition and concept of district cooling
Key components and system architecture, including different types of chillers and their roles
Thermodynamics of cooling, covering principles of heat transfer, thermodynamics cycles in chillers
Fluid dynamics in district cooling systems
Flow characteristics, pipe sizing, and hydraulics
Pumping systems and chiller plant dynamics
Cooling tower operations and their significance
Chilled water distribution, pipes and their insulation
Return water pipes in district cooling, their function and significance
Ensuring the efficient return of water to the chiller plant
Importance of backup chillers for system reliability
Heat Exchangers in district cooling, their functions, types and role in transferring cold energy to building systems
Understanding the internal water circulation within buildings
Pumps and pipes for efficient distribution
Air Handling Units (AHUs) and Fan Coil Units (FCUs) and their role at the consumer end
Thermostats and controls for effective temperature regulation
Afternoon session: Environmental Impact and Sustainability
Energy efficiency considerations and greenhouse gas emissions
Space savings allowing green roofs and solar installations
Contribution to smart city planning and integration of green energy solutions
Presentation of successful district cooling systems including Punggol Digital District, Megajana, Northgate, Fraicheur de Paris, Districlima, Climaespaco, Tabreed
District Cooling Systems (DCS) Planning and Engineering
Morning session: Development of a District Cooling System (DCS)
Evaluate the needs of the territory
Identify buildings to be connected and load forecasting
Identification of land for DCS plant and local sources of renewable and or recoverable energy
Differentiation between greenfield and brownfield projects
System sizing, capacity planning centralised and decentralised design
Sustainable features for optimising energy efficiency based on lifecycle cost analysis
Role of thermal energy storage in district cooling
Storing excess chilled water for peak demand
Afternoon session: New Technologies and Innovation in DCS
Chiller technology: oil free and variable speed
Digital technology:  AI- and multi-objective optimisation control
Plant operation: Addressing operation risks such as Low DT syndrome
Plant maintenance including preventive and predictive maintenance, water treatment and replacement
Digital tool to support including BMS and SCADA for monitoring and control and CMMS
Plantroom and cooling tower areas (Assessing the role of key components in real-world scenarios)
Economic Viability, Regulatory Landscape and Class Assessment
Morning session: Economic Viability and Regulatory Landscape
Business plan: CAPEX estimation, OPES estimation and economic analysis
Analysis of the average price of cooling compared to the market price
Capital intensive project: Initial investment versus operational savings
Key role of the local government
Group workshops: Application of principles learned in real-world scenarios.
A Certificate of Attainment will be issued to participants who:
Attend at least 75% of the course
Undertake and pass non-credit bearing assessment during the course
Participants who meet the attendance requirement but do not pass the assessment will receive a Certificate of Participation.
The full fee for this course is S$5,450.00.
Funded under SkillsFuture Mid-Career Enhanced Subsidy (MCES)
All fees above include GST. GST applies to individuals and Singapore-registered companies.
